title: 108_hr2630
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" or the "CASE Act of 2003." It introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new clause for nonimmigrant aliens who possess critical information on alien smuggling organizations and are essential to criminal investigations. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to limit the number of nonimmigrant visas for aliens with critical information on alien smuggling organizations to 400 per fiscal year. If the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of State, or the Attorney General determines the identity of an individual is essential to an authorized criminal investigation, they may be admitted as a nonimmigrant. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to limit nonimmigrant visas for aliens with critical information on alien smuggling organizations to 400 per fiscal year. Officials can take lawful action to protect the identity of nonimmigrants and their family members if deemed necessary. SEC. 3. Adjustment of status of nonimmigrant to that of person admitted for permanent residence. Section 245(j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to adjust the status of a nonimmigrant admitted under a specific section to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence under certain conditions related to alien smuggling investigations. The Secretary of Homeland Security may adjust the status of a nonimmigrant admitted under a specific section to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence based on a recommendation of the Secretary of State or the Attorney General. If the identity of the person needs protection, officials can take necessary lawful actions for protection. SEC. 4. BRINGING IN AND HARBORING CERTAIN ALIENS. Criminal penalties for bringing aliens into the US illegally may be increased by up to 10 years if the offense is part of a commercial organization, aliens are transported in groups of 10 or more, and their transport endangers lives. A rewards program is established to assist in eliminating commercial alien smuggling. The rewards program established to combat commercial alien smuggling involves paying rewards to individuals providing information leading to the arrest or conviction of those involved in smuggling groups of 10 or more aliens in a way that endangers lives or poses health risks. The program is administered by the Secretary of Homeland Security in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State. The rewards program targets individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling, including those endangering lives or posing health risks by transporting groups of 10 or more aliens. Rewards are given for arrests, convictions, prevention of smuggling acts, dismantling of smuggling organizations, and identifying key leaders in smuggling operations. The commercial alien smuggling operation involves transporting groups of 10 or more aliens in a manner that endangers lives or poses a life-threatening health risk. Authorization of appropriations is available for carrying out this subsection, and protection measures are in place for individuals providing information or testimony. The identity of individuals providing information must be protected, with a maximum reward of $100,000 unless authorized by the Secretary of Homeland Security for combating commercial alien smuggling operations endangering lives. The Secretary of Homeland Security must personally approve rewards exceeding $50,000 for combating activities endangering lives or posing health risks. An outreach program will educate the public about penalties for bringing in and harboring aliens in violation of the law. The outreach program aims to educate the public about penalties for harboring aliens and the incentives for assisting in combating smuggling operations.
